conversations.content: The Ancient Accord: Part One
Once there was a dragon named Stribog who guarded the city of Odo. Just, kind, and righteous, he was revered by the people, and loved them all in return.
Stribog gave the people his wisdom as best he could. However, he would grant them advice alone, refusing to use his power to interfere in human matters.
For even the best-intended dragons can disrupt the world's balance by meddling in human conflicts, and so did they all abide by an ancient accord which forbade such actions.
One day, a neighboring town that revered the Firelord Agni—another dragon—launched an attack on Odo.
Upon hearing of the war, Stribog  hurried to meet with Agni, and the two of them agreed not to intervene directly in the fight—though Stribog permitted his people to take up arms.
Within hours, Agni's forces retreated, leaving behind a massive wooden carving of Agni on the battlefield.
The soldiers of Odo were instantly suspicious, for they had heard tales of a similar carving being used to foment a surprise attack upon another unsuspecting city.
In this tale, the unsuspecting city took the carving behind its walls, only to discover that it was filled with enemy soldiers when they  emerged and sacked the town.
If Agni's soldiers were attempting a similar tactic, the people of Odo reasoned, they should encircle the carving and attack it before the soldiers could emerge.
Enacting this plan, they mounted an assault on the carving. But when it broke open, it was not soldiers that emerged, but gouts of flaming oil.
The oil raced forth and engulfed the city, turning it into an ocean of fire. The soldiers were burned to death in an instant, and Odo itself was lost.
Seeing this, Stribog let out a roar so loud it shook the heavens, for he knew Agni was behind the cowardly tactic. Quaking with rage, he flew off to confront his fellow dragon.
The Ancient Accord: Part Two
Stribog was certain the trick that doomed his people had been devised by Agni—who had sworn not to interfere in the conflict.
Stribog confronted Agni and accused him of trickery, claiming that the fire mana which sparked the blaze could only have come from him.
＂Fie on you, craven!＂ cried Stribog. ＂You have broken the ancient accord and interfered directly in the affairs of humans!＂ But Agni only chuckled at the other dragon's wrath.
＂It is you who are craven,＂ said Agni. ＂For you could have acted to protect your people as I did, but instead you were content to sit back and watch as they perished.＂
＂If you truly loved your people, you would have saved them.＂
＂You did not love your people—you merely loved the way they made you feel so very righteous about yourself. And because of that, you allowed them to die.＂
＂But look now on my people,＂ continued Agni. ＂See how happy they are? They know I have done this for them because I love them.
Stribog had no defense to give. Instead, he hung his head and flew away with the cheers of Agni's soldiers ringing in his ears.
For centuries, Stribog holed himself up in the mountains and avoided all  contact with humanity. He spent eons wondering what he should have done—and what was truly right.
He had wanted to protect his people, but as a dragon, he had sworn not to interfere. And no matter how long he mulled over this terrible problem, the answer remained unclear.
But then Euden came to see Stribog. Sensing the blood in his veins—and seeing the light in his eyes—the dragon became excited for the first time in ages.
＂If you come to me as a king,＂ Stribog said, ＂then I shall grant you the power to shapeshift. But bound as I am by the ancient accord, I fear I can do no more.＂
Yet what will he do when the young man falls into peril? What choice will  he make? Stribog will need to find his own answers to these questions...
